qas.question: What do psychologists use to visually map emotional experiences?
Along with valence, what is the other of the two dimensions used to map emotional experiences?
What is the term for the feeling of energy or enervation created by an emotional experience?
What is the term for the degree to which an emotional experience feels positive or negative?
What component of emotion provides its perceived energy?
What do psychologists use to non-visually map emotional experiences?
Along with valence, what is the other of the three dimensions used to map emotional experiences?
What isn't the term for the feeling of energy or enervation created by an emotional experience?
What is the term for the degree to which an non-emotional experience feels positive or negative?
What component of non-emotion provides its perceived energy?

context: Through the use of <a0_0><b5_0>multidimensional scaling<b5_0/><a0_0/>, psychologists can map out similar emotional experiences, which allows a visual depiction of the "emotional distance" between experiences. A further step can be taken by looking at the map's dimensions of the emotional experiences. The emotional experiences are divided into two dimensions known as <a3_0><b8_0>valence<b8_0/><a3_0/> (how negative or positive the experience feels) and <a1_0><a2_0><b6_0><b7_0>arousal<b7_0/><b6_0/><a2_0/><a1_0/> (how energized or enervated the experience feels). These two dimensions can be depicted on a 2D coordinate map. This two-dimensional map was theorized to capture one important component of emotion called <a4_0>core affect<a4_0/>. <b9_0>Core affect<b9_0/> is not the only component to emotion, but gives the emotion its hedonic and felt energy.
